column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

The first Combined prime and store sale for a fortnight saw 2043 cattle penned. Despite most cattle presenting in fresh condition, quality was very mixed throughout the offering. Only three regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity restockers.  Buyer demand was selective throughout with preference for better quality types.  Prices received were in line with other selling centres relative to quality. Cattle were were drawn from Richmond to Chillagoe, and south to local and coastal areas.  

Lightweight young steers averaged 310c selling to 316c, similar heifers reached 205c to average 175c/kg. Steers above 200kg returning to the paddock reached 298c to average 258c to 278c/kg. Heifers to restockers sold to 230c to average 224c/kg. Yearling steers above 280kg to live export sold to 290c, restocker steers averaged 251c/kg. Yearling steers above 400kg to feed made to 270c to average 255c, those suitable for live export averaged 276c/ kg. A good sample of yearling heifers above 330kg to feed averaged 224c/kg. 

Grown steers above 400kg to live export averaged 275c, steers to processors averaged 255c/kg. Heavy grown steers to processors topped at 260c to average 259c/kg.  A good supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 230c to average 216c/kg.

Heavy bullocks to export slaughter topped at 270c, most averaged 250-267c/kg. Medium weight 3 score cow to processors sold to 222c to average 209c to 215c, while prime heavyweight cows sold to and averaged 218c/kg.  Heavy bulls to processors reached 256c to average 235, bulls to feed destined for live export averaged 254c/kg.

A large sample of cows and calves sold from $575 to $1,0000 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham
